(c) The client shall then be given both written and oral instructions on how to care for the piercing during the healing process. (d) A facility that limits its piercing practice to the piercing of the lobe of the ear with pre-sterilized, single-use stud and clasp piercing systems shall be exempt from regulatory requirements of this article. Compliance with the requirements for this exemption may be verified by inspection at the option of the board of health. (Ord. of 3-11-2013, § 1) Sec. 52-137. - Compliance. (a) A body art studio shall operate in compliance with these rules and with a valid body art studio permit issued by the county board of health. (b) A body artist shall perform body art procedures in compliance with these rules and with a valid body artist permit issued by the county board of health. (Ord. of 3-11-2013, § 1) Sec. 52-138. - Enforcement and penalties. (a) Enforcement of the rules and regulations shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A 31-5. (b) The board of health may refuse to grant a permit for the operation of any body art studio which does not fulfill the minimum requirements of the rules and regulations and may revoke a permit which has been issued and invoke other sanctions if a studio violates any of these rules and regulations. Before any order is entered refusing a permit applied for or revoking a permit, the applicant or permit holder shall be offered an opportunity for a hearing before the county board of health as provided in Article 1 of Chapter 5 of Title 31 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. The notice of refusal or revocation shall contain directions on how a hearing may be requested. (c) The board of health is empowered to institute proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enjoining violations of an applicable provision of Title 31 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated or of these rules and regulations. (d) Any person or entity violating any provision of this regulation shall, upon conviction thereof, or upon entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere thereto, shall be punished by a fine, not exceeding $1,000.00 or by imprisonment for a term not more than 60 days, or by both fine and imprisonment. (e) Owners shall be responsible for ensuring agents and employees fully comply with the provisions of these regulations and shall be liable for any violation hereof. (Ord. of 3-11-2013, § 1) Sec. 52-139. - Effective date. (a) The provisions of these rules shall become effective ten days after adoption by the county board of commissioners. (Ord. of 3-11-2013, § 1)

div.head: Chapter 53 - SPECIAL EVENTS
div.p: Sec. 53-1. - Definition. Special event shall mean any organized activity having its own entertainment, recreation, festival, foot or vehicle race, parade, march, rally or assembly which takes place on a public road, sideway or right-of-way or occurs on private property and impacts local government services by creating a reasonable and foreseeable need for additional police, fire, ambulance or public works services, including but not limited to traffic control, crowd control and security, a typical road/right-of-way repair, maintenance or cleaning, or heightened fire or ambulance presence. Any special event having more than two hundred fifty (250) persons in attendance shall be presumed to impact local government services. Sec. 53-2. - Permit required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct any special event in Butts County without obtaining a valid permit for said event. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct any special event in Butts County outside the specific geographical area approved on the permit. (c) Except for clean up activities, it shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct any special event in Butts County before or after the time approved on the permit. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to submit a false or misleading application for a special event. Sec. 53-4. - Special conditions of permit. Prior to the issuance of a permit, the county administrator shall review and circulate to all appropriate county departments and/or agencies that would be affected by the activities of the proposed event. Any special conditions, including the cost to provide any specific services, shall be delineated in writing to the county administrator. Sec. 53-5. - Final approval of permit. (a) The county administrator is authorized to approve and issue a permit for a special event after consideration of all special conditions and payment of all associated costs. (b) After proper filing of the application, the county administrator shall be allowed fifteen (15) working days to review the application and issue the permit. (c) All special events occurring on public property shall comply with the requirements or policy of the county concerning parades and demonstrations. (d) The county administrator may issue a permit subject to reasonable and content neutral special conditions necessary to protect the health, welfare and morals of the general public, as determined by the county administrator. (e) If the event the County Administrator denies the application for permit, the county administrator shall notify the applicant in writing the reason(s) for the denial. (f) Any applicant may appeal the denial of the application for special event permit, or the imposition of any special condition to the board of commissioners who shall take up the matter at its next regular meeting. Appeals may be made by filing a written notice of appeal with the county administrator or county clerk. Sec. 53-6. - Permit fees. (a) All persons receiving a special even permit shall pay a permit fee equal to the actual cost of services provided by the county for such special event. Applicants shall pay the estimated cost of county services at the time the permit is issued. Any additional costs of services shall be paid by the applicant upon receipt of notice, and any overpayment shall be refunded. (b) The permit fee may be waived or reduced by the county administrator for special events conducted by charitable or non-profit organizations, based upon the positive benefit to the county or community, as determined in the sole discretion of the county administrator. Sec. 53-7. - Non-sponsorship and cessation. (a) The issuance of a special event permit and providing of county services due to such event shall in no way mean Butts County, the county administrator, board of commissioners or other employee of the county condones, supports, sponsors, or is a participant of such special event or the person or entity conducting the same. (b) Notwithstanding the issuance of a special event permit, the Butts County sheriff's department of county administrator may terminate any special event or activity endangering the health, safety, morals and welfare of the citizens of Butts County or the participants in such event or activity. Sec. 53-8. - Exemptions. (a) Special events conducted by religious organizations having a permanent place of worship within Butts County, Georgia, or any licensed or accredited educational facility shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. (b) Funeral processions conducted under the supervision of a funeral director in conjunction with funeral shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. Sec. 53-9. - Administration and enforcement; penalties. (a) The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the county sheriff and deputies, Butts County Code Enforcement officers or other person officially designated by the board of commissioners to enforce the provisions of the Official Code of Butts County, Georgia or this article. (b) Proceedings to enforce this article shall be tried in the county magistrate court. Any person, firm or corporation who pleads guilty, nolo contender or is convicted of violating the provisions of this chapter may be sentenced as provided in O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 or such other general laws as may be in the future enacted to provide for punishment and penalties that may be imposed by the magistrate courts of this state. Each violation of this chapter may be punished according to the provisions of section 1-19 of the Official Code of Butts County, Georgia. (c) In addition to its right to seek all legal and equitable remedies, Butts County, Georgia, shall have the express right to seek injunctive relief against any person, entity or organization conducting an event in violation of this chapter. Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as granting or vesting in any person or entity other than Butts County, Georgia, its commissioners or agents, any right of enforcement by legal, equitable or injunctive process.

div.head: Chapter 54 - MANUFACTURED HOMES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 46; planning, ch. 66; roads and bridges, ch. 70; solid waste, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90; zoning ordinance, ch. 100; development ordinance, ch. 101. State Law reference— Ad valorem taxation of mobile homes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440 et seq.; issuance of mobile home location permits; display of decals, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492; The Uniform Standards Code for Manufactured Homes Act, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-130 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 54-1—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARK OWNER REPORTS
Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Mobile home park owner means anyone who leases or owns land that is used to rent spaces to park mobile homes. Reporting forms means those forms that are provided by the county tax assessors or the county tax commissioner to provide the required information as set out in this article. (Ord. of 3-7-1988, § 4.1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-32. - Information required for submission. All mobile home park owners shall be required to submit upon forms supplied by the county tax assessors or the county tax commissioner on or before January 10 of each year the following information: (1) The names and mailing address of the owners of all mobile homes located in their park on the first day of the year of reporting; (2) The year, model, make, width and length, and serial number of each mobile home; and (3) The decal number. (Ord. of 3-7-1988, § 5.0) Sec. 54-33. - Reporting the moving of mobile homes. (a) Each mobile home park owner shall immediately notify the county tax assessors or the county tax commissioner of anyone attempting to move a mobile home out of their mobile home park. (b) Each mobile home park owner shall notify the county tax assessors or tax commissioners of anyone moving a mobile home into their park within ten days of the moving. (Ord. of 3-7-1988, § 5.1) Sec. 54-35. - Enforcement of article. (a) Enforcing officers. (1) The board of commissioners designates the tax commissioner to serve as the enforcement officer of this article. (2) The county commissioners do hereby grant authority to any county tax assessor or their assistants, any employee of the county tax commissioner as well as the county tax commissioner, assistant tax commissioner or employee and any county deputy sheriff, as well as the county sheriff to issue citations for the violation of this article. (b) Court proceedings. (1) Violation of this article shall be tried upon citation as described in section 54-35(b) and may be tried with or without prosecuting attorney as well as upon accusation. The county attorney shall serve as prosecuting attorney. (2) Violation of this article shall be tried in the county magistrate court, and shall be tried in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq. (3) Nothing in this article shall prevent the board of commissioners or the county tax commissioner from bringing any civil action for injunction, mandamus or other proceedings to present, correct or abate any violation of this article. No sanction penalty or remedy prescribed in this article shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other sanction, penalty or to any other remedy, penalty or sanction by law. (Ord. of 3-7-1988, § 7.0) Secs. 54-36—54-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL EXCEPTION TEMPORARY HARDSHIP PERMITS FOR MANUFACTURED HOUSING[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note—The requirements for the issuance of special exception temporary hardship permits for manufactured housing codified in this article were adopted by the county as appendix N (see section 106(B)(8)) to the county's zoning ordinance on March 16, 1998.
Sec. 54-71. - Application procedure for temporary physical hardship permit. The procedure for applying for a temporary physical hardship permit is as follows: (1) Such permits are issued for 12 months. (2) Persons requesting a physical hardship permit must have an illness and/or disability that requires attention not otherwise available, and the manufactured home must be located on or adjacent to the property of the persons to provide care. (3) The applicant must produce a doctor's certificate that states the nature of the disability or illness. (4) The applicant must show substantial proof that he has no other place to live and that placement of a manufactured home is the only viable solution. (5) The applicant and land owner must sign an affidavit stating that the manufactured home will be removed within 90 days when the hardship no longer exists. (6) Any manufactured home issued a temporary construction hardship permit must have been construction within the standards established under the National Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards Act (U.S. Public Law 93-383) and bear an insignia issued by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). (7) Any manufactured home issued a temporary physical hardship permit must be placed so as to meet front, side and rear setback requirements as established in the county zoning ordinance for the zoning district in which the home is to be placed. (8) Any manufactured home issued a temporary physical hardship permit must be placed on the lot such that it can meet wastewater disposal requirements of the county health department. (9) The Butts County Planning and Zoning Commission and the Butts County Board of Commissioners will abide by a code of ethics that states that any member with a personal interest in an item to be discussed will not vote on that item. (10) In cases where construction goes beyond the original six months permit period, all holders of such permits must reapply for a new temporary construction hardship permit at the time each six-month period lapses. The applicant must personally appear before the county board of appeals hearing for renewal. In no case will a permit be renewed when 18 months have passed since the original permit was issued. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § A) Sec. 54-72. - Application procedure for temporary construction hardship permit. The procedure for applying for a temporary construction hardship permit is as follows: (1) Such permits are issued for six months. (2) Persons requesting a construction hardship permit must have definite plans for construction of a permanent home on the property where the manufactured home is to be located and use the manufactured home only as a temporary residence until such construction is complete. (3) Construction of the permanent dwelling must be complete within 18 months of the original issuance of the temporary construction hardship permit. (4) The applicant must show substantial evidence that the temporary occupation of a manufactured home is his only recourse for shelter. (5) The applicant must own the land, or be paying for it. (6) The applicant must submit house plans to the planning and zoning commission prior to issuance of the temporary construction hardship permit. (7) Prior to the issuance of the temporary construction hardship permit, the applicant and the county building inspector must work out a written time schedule under which the house is to be constructed. In no case can construction begin more than three months after the date of issuance of the original temporary construction hardship permit. (8) The applicant must furnish proof to the planning and zoning commission that adequate financing is available for construction of the house. (9) The applicant must sign an affidavit that he will comply with the written construction schedule worked out with the building inspector, and will comply with all requirements set up temporary construction hardship permit. This affidavit must also state that the applicant will remove the manufactured home from the property upon completion of construction of the permanent house. (10) Any manufactured home issued a temporary construction hardship permit must have been constructed within the standards established under the National Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards Act (U.S. Public Law 93-383) and bear an insignia issued by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). (11) Any manufactured home issued a temporary construction hardship permit must be placed so as to meet front, side and rear setback requirements as established in the county zoning ordinance for the zoning district in which the home is to be placed. (12) Any manufactured home issued a temporary construction hardship permit must be placed on the lot such that it can meet wastewater disposal requirements of the county health department. (13) The Butts County Planning and Zoning Commission and the Butts County Board of Commissioners will abide by a code of ethics that states that any member with a personal interest in an item to be discussed will not vote on that item. (14) In cases where construction goes beyond the original six months permit period, all holders of such permits must reapply for a new temporary construction hardship permit at the time each six-month period lapses. The applicant must personally appear before the Butts County Planning and Zoning Commission and the Butts County Board of Commissioners hearing for renewal. In no case will a permit be renewed when 18 months have passed since the original permit was issued. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § B) Sec. 54-73. - Certified hardship; conditions required for certification. A person having a certified hardship shown according to the procedure contained in this section and meeting any one of the following conditions may apply to the planning and zoning commission for the special exception permit: (1) The applicant for the special exception is to be the owner and occupant of the temporary unit and is 65 years of age or older. (2) The applicant for the special exception is to be the owner and occupant of the temporary unit; at least one member of his family who will reside in the unit is 65 years of age or older. (3) The applicant for the special exception is to be the owner and occupant of the temporary unit and is physically disabled and requires frequent attendance by others for medical or physical care. (4) The applicant for the special exception is to be the owner and occupant of the temporary unit, and at least one member of his family is physically disabled and requires frequent attendance by others for medical or physical care. (5) The applicant for the special exception is not to be the owner and occupant of the temporary unit but at least one of the residents of the unit is a member of the applicant's family and is 65 years of age or older. (6) The applicant for the special exception is not to be the owner and occupant of the temporary unit but at least one of the residents of the unit is a member of the applicant/owner's family and is physically disabled and requires frequent attendance by others for medical or physical care. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § C) Sec. 54-74. - Doctor's certification. In order to determine if the need for the special exception permit presented by the applicant is a certified hardship, the planning and zoning commission will require a doctor's certificate, currently dated, attesting to the health of the person who is asserted to be physically disabled and also attesting to the need for frequent attendance upon such a person by other people. The certificate will be requested by the planning and zoning commission directly from the doctor in attendance upon the person who is asserted to be disabled. The applicant will be required to sign a release to the doctor for such information to be supplied to the planning and zoning commission prior to any action by the planning and zoning commission or the Butts County Board of Commissioners to obtain the certificate from the doctor and any possible subsequent issuance of the special exception permit. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § D) Sec. 54-75. - Application procedure for a special exception permit for a temporary manufactured home for a certified hardship. The procedure for applying for a special exception permit for a temporary manufactured home for a certified hardship is as follows: (1) Application should be made to the planning and zoning commission for the special exception permit for a temporary manufactured home for certified hardship. (2) The planning and zoning will explain to the applicant all conditions and limitations attached to such a permit and will secure the written certification of the applicant that he understands and will abide by those conditions if issued the special exception permit. (3) The planning and zoning will consider such applications, and upon determining that all requirements have been met for such a permit, will make a recommendation to the Butts County Board of Commissioner, who will then issue the special exception permit upon a favorable vote. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § E) Sec. 54-76. - Building permit required for installation of temporary manufactured home; procedure. Upon being granted a special exception permit to allow a temporary manufactured home for certified hardship, the applicant must then apply to the zoning administrator for a building permit for the installation of the temporary manufactured home. The procedure is as follows: (1) Plans for a water/well and sewage/septic system suitable for the temporary manufactured home proposed to be installed on the site must be submitted to the county health department for its review and approval. (2) Upon securing concurrence of the county health department of the proposed water and sewage systems to serve the proposed temporary manufactured home, the owner should present evidence of such approval to the zoning administrator and apply for a building permit for installation of the proposed temporary manufactured home, including the water and sewage systems. (3) Upon approval of the zoning administrator and receipt of the building permit, the owner should proceed with installation of the proposed temporary manufactured home, including water and sewage systems. The zoning administrator will provide required inspections of these systems during and upon completion of construction. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § F) Sec. 54-77. - Conditions applying to special exception permits issued for temporary use of manufactured home for hardship. The following conditions apply to special exception permits issued for temporary use of a manufactured home for hardship: (1) It is temporary and valid only for a specific period of time. It must be renewed every 12 months. (2) A development plan must be submitted showing the proposed locations of the principal building, the water and sewage systems, and the temporary manufactured home. That development plan must be approved by the planning and zoning commission before issuing the temporary special exception permit. (3) During its period of approval, the temporary manufactured home must be connected to the approved water and sewage systems. (4) The temporary manufactured home must be removed within 30 days of either the expiration of the special exception permit for the temporary manufactured home or upon finding of the planning and zoning commission, upon its own application or that of any aggrieved party and after giving due notice to all concerned parties and granting full opportunity for a hearing, that the conditions for which the special exception was granted no longer exist, whichever is earlier. (5) The temporary manufactured home must be either a class B or class C manufactured home. (6) No more than one such unit is permitted per lot. (7) The unit must be located entirely within the rear setback of the principal dwelling, as shown on the approved development plan. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(4), app. N, § G) Secs. 54-78—54-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - MANUFACTURED HOME REPORTING[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note—Ord. No. 6(1)2000, §§ 1.0—8.2, adopted June 1, 2000, set out provisions pertaining to mobile home reporting regulations. Said ordinance did not specifically amend this Code; hence said provisions have been included as §§ 54-101, 54-106, 54-111, 54-116, 54-117, 54-121, 54-122, 54-126—54-128, 54-136—54-138 and 54-146—54-148 at the discretion of the editor to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table.
DIVISION 1. - PURPOSES
Sec. 54-101. - [Purpose.] The Butts County Board of Commissioners, in furtherance of its responsibility as the governing authority of the county, desires to see that ad valorem taxes are equally assessed, uniformly applied, and properly collected. To that end, and in recognition of the responsibilities delegated to Butts County by the General Assembly at O.C.G.A. § 48-5-490 et seq., this ordinance is adopted for the purpose of insuring that ad valorem taxes on manufactured homes are uniformly and properly collected. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 1.0, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-102—54-105. - Reserved. Sec. 54-106. - [Enactment clause.] The board of commissioners of Butts County, Georgia, in furtherance of Article 5 of Title 48, Official Code of Georgia, hereby ordains and enacts into law the following articles and sections. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 2.0, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-107—54-110. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - TITLE OF ORDINANCE
Sec. 54-111. - [Title.] This article shall be known and may be cited as "The Manufactured Home Reporting Ordinance." (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 3.0, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-112—54-115. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - DEFINITIONS OF TERMS USED IN THIS ARTICLE
Sec. 54-116. - General. Except as otherwise provided herein, all words shall have the customary dictionary meaning. The present tense includes the future tense. The singular numbers include the plural and the plural includes the singular. The word "person" includes a firm, corporation, association, organization, trust or partnership. The use of the masculine gender includes the feminine, and the use of the feminine gender includes the masculine. The word "shall" is always mandatory. The word "may" is permissive and is not mandatory. The "board of commissioners" refers to the Board of Commissioners of Butts County, Georgia. The "tax commissioner" refers to the Tax Commissioner of Butts County. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 4.0, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-117. - Specific definitions. When used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning given in this section: Manufactured home shall have the same definition as set form at O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440(3). The terms "mobile home" and "manufactured home" are synonymous as used in this article. Reporting forms means those forms that are provided by the Butts County Tax Commissioner to obtain the information required by this article. Responsible land owner means (1) any person who leases or owns land that is used to rent spaces to park manufactured homes occupied by others, and (2) any person who owns, leases or manages for a fee land that is made available to others who have placed a manufactured home on the land but who do not own the land in fee simple but instead possess a tenancy, land sales contract, a contract to convey a deed in the future, or some other arrangement that does not immediately convey a deed in fee simple to the occupant. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 4.1, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-118—54-120. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - REQUIREMENTS FOR RESPONSIBLE LAND OWNERS
Sec. 54-121. - General. All responsible land owners shall be required to submit upon forms supplied by the Butts County Tax Commissioner the following information: (1) The names and mailing addresses of the occupants of all manufactured homes located in parks or on lands not owned by the occupants, in fee simple, and (2) The year, model, make, width and length, and serial number of each manufactured home, and (3) The decal number, affixed to the manufactured home as issued by the county; (4) The forms required by this section shall be filed with the tax commissioner on an annual basis unless a change of occupancy occurs, in which case section 54-122 shall apply. Completed forms for occupants residing in the county on the date this article is adopted shall be filed with the tax commissioner no later than 30 days following the adoption of this article. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 5.0, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-122. - Reporting the moving of manufactured homes. (a) Each responsible land owner shall immediately notify the county tax commissioner of anyone attempting to move a manufactured home off of the responsible land owner's property. This notice must be provided within 48 hours of the time the responsible land owner has reason to believe the manufactured home may be moved. (b) Each responsible land owner shall notify the county tax commissioner of anyone moving a manufactured home onto their land within five days of moving. The form required in section 54-121 must be completed and shall be filed with the tax commissioner. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 5.1, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-123—54-125. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - REQUIREMENTS FOR OCCUPANTS; PERMITS FOR MOVING MANUFACTURED HOMES
Sec. 54-126. - General. Any person wishing to move a manufactured home into or out of Butts County, Georgia upon land that such person does not own in fee simple must have a permit and decal as required by this article. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 6.0, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-127. - Moving a manufactured home into Butts County. (a) Any person wishing to move a manufactured home into the county that is to be located upon land that such person does not own in fee simple must: (1) Obtain a manufactured home location permit and decal issued by the Butts County Community Development Department; and (2) Before a permit and decal shall be issued by the Butts County Community Development Department an approval must be obtained from the Butts County Tax Commissioner showing that the taxes on the manufactured home have been paid in the previous county of residence. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 6.1, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-128. - Moving a manufactured home out of Butts County. (a) Any person wishing to remove a manufactured home from any land in the county that is not owned by such person in fee simple must obtain a permit prior to the moving of the manufactured home; and (b) A removal permit may be obtained without cost from the county tax commissioner upon the payment of any taxes due on the manufactured home or upon proof that the taxes have been paid on the manufactured home. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 6.2, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-129—54-135. - Reserved. DIVISION 7. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 54-136. - Enforcing officers. (a) The tax commissioner shall have the authority to determine if taxes have been paid and if permits may be issued. (b) The code enforcement officer, the sheriff or any deputy sheriff of Butts County, Georgia, may issue citations for the violation of this article. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 7.0, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-137. - Court proceedings. (a) Violations of this article shall be tried upon citation as described in article VII of this article and may be tried with or without prosecuting attorney as well as upon accusation. The Butts County Attorney may serve as prosecuting attorney. (b) Violations of this article shall be tried in the Magistrate Court of Butts County, Georgia, and shall be tried in accordance with the Official Code of Georgia, Annotated, Title 15, Chapter 10. (c) Nothing in this article shall prevent the Butts County Board of Commissioners or the Butts County Tax Commissioner from bringing any civil action for injunction, mandamus or other proceedings to prevent, correct, or abate any violation of this article. No sanction, penalty, or remedy prescribed herein shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other sanction, penalty or to any other remedy, penalty or sanction by law. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 7.1, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-138. - Penalties for violation. (a) Anyone found guilty of violating this article or any part thereof shall be fined in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-5-493. (b) Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate violation. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 7.2, 6-1-2000) Secs. 54-139—54-145. - Reserved. DIVISION 8. - LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS
Sec. 54-146. - Severability. Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this article be declared invalid for any reason, the remainder of said article shall not be affected thereby. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 8.0, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-147. - Repealer clause. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are expressly repealed. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 8.1, 6-1-2000) Sec. 54-148. - Effective date. This article shall become effective and be in force from the 1st day of June, 2000. (Ord. No. 6(1)2000, § 8.2, 6-1-2000) Chapters 55—57 - RESERVED

div.head: Chapter 58 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
Chapter 62 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 34. State Law reference— Establishment of recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 62-1. - [Prohibited specified acts in parks and recreations areas.] (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, in any manner, to mark on, deface, injure, displace, dig, excavate, remove, or construct on any real or personal property located in any park or recreational areas owned by the county, except when done with special written permission granted by the board of commissioners of Butts County or the director of the parks and recreation department. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle on any road in a park or recreational area owned by the county in excess of 25 miles per hour. It shall also be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle in excess of 15 miles per hour within 200 feet of any intensive-use area in the park or recreational area. As used in this paragraph, the term "vehicle" means any wheeled conveyance for the transportation of persons or materials. As used in this paragraph, the term "intensive-use area" means a picnic area, pool area, a check-in-station, or a ball or sporting event field. (c) It shall be unlawful to hunt, trap or otherwise pursue or catch any wildlife in any park or recreational area owned by the county. It shall also be unlawful to shoot into a park or recreational area from beyond the boundaries of such park or recreational area. (d) It shall be unlawful for any intoxicated person to enter or remain in any park or recreational area owned by the county. It shall also be unlawful for any person to consume, use or possess alcoholic beverages or intoxicants in any park or recreational area owned by the county. (e) It shall be unlawful to be under the influence of any drugs or to solicit the purchase or sale of any drugs in a park or recreational area owned by the county. (f) It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess in any park or recreational area owned by the county any fireworks, explosives, or firecrackers unless such use has been previously approved by the Butts County Board of Commissioners. It shall also be unlawful for any person to use or possess in any park or recreational area any firearms, bows and arrows, spring guns, air rifles, slingshots, or any other device which discharges projectiles by any means, unless previously approved by the county board of commissioners. (g) It shall be unlawful to bring any animals, pets, domesticated animals, or reptiles, including but not limited to dogs and cats, into any park or recreational area owned by the county. The exclusive exception to this restriction is for seeing eye dogs. Certain events, however, that by their nature require the presence of animals may be exempt from this prohibition. For example, rodeo events, horse shows, dog shows and farm exhibitions may be exempt if prior written authorization has been obtained from the Director of the Parks and Recreation Department of Butts County. (h) It shall be unlawful to refuse to leave a park or recreational area owned by the county upon being ordered to do so by a law enforcement officer or an agent or employee of the county for violating any of the prohibitions pronounced in this section. (i) It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle overnight in any park or recreational area owned by the county without prior written approval from the Director of the Parks and Recreation Department of Butts County. (j) It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in a park or recreational area owned by the county at a location where signs prohibit parking. This paragraph also prohibits parking in designated "permit only areas" without an approved parking permit. (k) It shall be unlawful to use tobacco inside any recreational center, gymnasium or public recreational area owned by the county board of commissioners. "Public area" means any enclosed areas or portion thereof to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including but not limited to: Lobbies, reception areas, offices and restrooms. (l) It shall be unlawful to use tobacco on any athletic fields, courts or tracks owned by the county board of commissioners. This shall include all coaching and playing areas, inside dugouts, spectator viewing areas, restrooms, concession stands and press boxes. Provided, designated smoking areas may be established for each of the outdoor athletic facilities. (m) In joint-use facilities belonging to the public school system, the city(ies) or private entities, etc., which have their own tobacco policies, parks and recreation participants, officials and spectators shall follow the policy of the entity hosting the parks and recreation event. In the absence of a policy regarding the use of tobacco, the policies pronounced in subsections (k) and (l) shall apply. (n) Violations of this section shall be tried in the Magistrate Court of Butts County, under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 et seq. The maximum penalty that may be imposed for each violation of this section shall be a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed 180 days, or both. (Ord. No. 5(1)2000, §§ 1—14, 5-1-2000) Secs. 62-2—62-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Sec. 62-31. - Established. The Jackson-Butts County Parks and Recreation Board, called "the board," in this article is hereby established. Such board shall function in an advisory capacity to the recreation director. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 1) Sec. 62-32. - Duties. The duties of the board shall include responsibilities such as to initiate, plan, organize, implement, and coordinate public recreation programs and activities for the county; to initiate, plan, design and recommend a system of parks, facilities and other spaces which will be necessary to accommodate the public's need and demand for parks and recreation activities; to prepare and develop rules and regulations by which parks and recreation programs may operate; to monitor and evaluate the effectiveness of parks and recreation programs; to advise and recommend ways and means by which parks and recreation programs may be improved or strengthened; to develop new programs and activities as public need may dictate; to develop a system of fees and charges for use of parks and recreation facilities or for participation in parks and recreation programs; and other duties and responsibilities as may be conferred by the City of Jackson and the county from time to time. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 2) Sec. 62-33. - Powers. In order to perform the duties enumerated in section 62-32, the board shall be responsible for and have the following authority: (1) Adopt bylaws and other rules of procedure to achieve its purposes and functions. (2) Establish rules governing participation in parks and recreation programs. (3) Establish rules governing the hours of operation and use of county parks and facilities. (4) Adjudicate complaints, disputes or other grievances from the public arising out of parks and recreation activities. (5) Evaluate programs and activities which are offered from year to year. (6) File an annual report with the board of commissioners relative to the program accomplishments for the preceding fiscal year. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 3) Sec. 62-34. - Membership. The board shall be representative of the community and shall consist of seven members who shall be residents of the county and who shall serve without compensation. Each county commissioner shall appoint one member from his district, and the City of Jackson shall appoint two members. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 4) Sec. 62-35. - Terms of office. The terms of office of the members of the board shall be for two years, provided that the initial members who hold an odd-numbered seat shall serve terms which will expire on December 31, 1993, and the terms of those members who hold an even-numbered seat would expire on December 31, 1994. Thereafter, the terms of all members shall be for a period of two years. Members whose terms have expired shall continue to serve as members until their successors have been appointed. Nothing contained in this section shall preclude the reappointment of any member whose term may be expiring or who has served in the past. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 5) Sec. 62-36. - Election of officers. The board shall elect from its membership a chairman and other officers as may be desired. Officers shall be elected on a calendar-year basis and may be reelected for succeeding terms. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 6) Sec. 62-37. - Meetings. The board shall meet at least on a monthly basis. The regular meeting schedule shall be adopted each year at the first meeting of the year and shall be publicized. Meetings shall be conducted in accordance with the Georgia Open Meeting's Law, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 7) Sec. 62-38. - Quorum. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members of the board serving at the time the quorum is called. (Res. of 1-4-1993, § 8) Chapters 63—65 - RESERVED

div.head: Chapter 66 - PLANNING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; manufactured homes, ch. 54; roads and bridges, ch. 70; signs, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 90; zoning ordinance, ch. 100; development ordinance, ch. 101. State Law reference— Coordinated and comprehensive planning by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 66-1. - Miscellaneous provisions not affected by Code. Nothing in this chapter or in the resolution adopting this chapter shall affect: (1) The resolution adopted on 4-7-1997, approving the county comprehensive plan, or any amendment thereto; or (2) The resolution adopted on 6-5-1995, amending the county land use plan to incorporate River Corridor Protection Criteria, or any amendment thereto. All such resolutions are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out in this chapter. Secs. 66-2—66-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Sec. 66-36. - Finding of necessity. Each of the boards of commissioners severally finds and declares that there is a need for a joint development authority to function in Butts, Henry, Lamar and Spalding Counties in order to promote trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities for the public good and the general welfare; to promote the general welfare of the state; and to reduce unemployment to the greatest extent possible within Butts, Henry, Lamar and Spalding Counties. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-37. - Authority and purpose of article. This article is adopted pursuant to the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.) as the same was amended by the General Assembly of Georgia at the 1995 session thereof and is intended to comply therewith and shall be governed thereby for the purpose of permitting business enterprises in the four counties to qualify for the tax credits given for each new full-time job created and for all other purposes permitted by such act. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-38. - Board of directors to govern; composition. The authority shall be governed by a board of directors consisting of three taxpaying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Butts County, Georgia, from the members of the Butts County Industrial Development Authority, three taxpaying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Henry County, Georgia, from the members of the Henry County Development Authority, three taxpaying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Lamar County, Georgia, from the members of the Lamar County Development Authority, and three taxpaying members to be appointed by the board of commissioners of Spalding County, Georgia, from the members of the Griffin Spalding County Development Authority. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-40. - Compensation of directors. The directors shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be reimbursed for their actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-41. - Election of officers; quorum. The board of directors shall elect a chair, a vice-chair, a secretary-treasurer and such other officers, and the chair shall appoint such committees, as shall be necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of and to conduct the affairs of the authority. A majority of the directors shall constitute a quorum, but no action may be taken by the board without the affirmative vote of a majority of the full membership of the board. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-42. - Meetings. The board of directors shall meet quarterly on the second Wednesday of January, March, June and September of each year. The meeting place shall rotate among Butts, Henry, Lamar and Spalding Counties, pursuant to written notice to be sent by the secretary at least seven days before each meeting. Special meetings may be held at the call of the chair or any three directors upon such reasonable notice as the exigencies of the situation permit. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-43. - Bylaws; enforcement and amendment; perpetual existence. (a) The authority may make bylaws and regulations for its governance and may delegate to one or more of its officers, agents and employees such powers and duties as may be deemed necessary and proper. The authority shall have perpetual existence. (b) The bylaws and the operational business plan of the authority shall be amended to comprehend the entry of Lamar County into this authority. The bylaws and operational business plan may be amended at any regular or called meeting of the authority by a majority of all the directors; provided, however, that written notice of the proposed amendment shall have been furnished to each director at least two weeks in advance of the meeting where the change is to be considered. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Sec. 66-44. - Amendment of article. This article may be amended at any time by concurrent resolution of the boards of commissioners of Butts, Henry, Lamar and Spalding Counties, Georgia. (Res. of 10-16-1995) Secs. 66-45—66-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFF-STREET PARKING AND SERVICE FACILITIES STANDARDS[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note—The standards for off-street parking and service facilities codified in this article were adopted by the county as appendix I to the county's zoning ordinance on March 16, 1998. Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86.
Sec. 66-76. - Scope of article. This article covers specifications for off-street parking and service facilities in the county. Requirements for such facilities are specified by zoning district in the county zoning ordinance. Such zoning ordinance refers the reader to this article for specifications of required facilities. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(1), app. I, § 101) Sec. 66-77. - General standards for parking space design. (a) Spaces must not be reduced. Off-street parking spaces must not be reduced below the minimum required number for the use or facility to which they are assigned. (b) Drainage, construction and maintenance. All off-street parking, loading and service areas must be drained so as to prevent damage to abutting properties and/or public streets, and must be constructed of materials which will ensure a surface resistant to erosion. All such areas must be at all times maintained at the expense of the owners in a clean, orderly and dustfree condition to the extent that it does not create a nuisance. (c) Separation from walkways, sidewalks and streets. All off-street parking, loading and service areas must be separated from walkways, sidewalks and streets by curbing or other suitable protective device. (d) Parking area design. Parking stalls must have a minimum width of 9½ feet and length of 18 feet. There must be provided adequate interior driveways to connect each parking space with a public right-of-way. Interior driveways must be at least 24 feet wide where used with 90-degree angle parking, and at least 12 feet wide where used with 60-degree angle parking, and at least 12 feet wide where used with 45-degree angle parking, and at least 12 feet wide where used with parallel parking. Where there is no parking, interior driveways must be at least 12 feet wide for one-way traffic movement and at least 24 feet wide for two-way traffic movement. (e) Joint parking facilities. Two or more neighboring uses of the same or different types may provide joint parking facilities as long as the number of off-street parking spaces are not less than the sum of the individual requirements. (f) Pavement markings and signs. Each off-street parking space must be clearly marked, and directional arrows or signs must be provided wherever necessary. Markers, directional arrows and signs must be properly maintained so as to ensure their maximum efficiency. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(1), app. I, § 102) Sec. 66-78. - Number of parking spaces required. Off-street parking space must be provided and maintained as specified in the following schedule. For uses not specifically listed in this section, the parking requirements for the listed use most similar to the unlisted use in question, as determined by the zoning administrator, will apply. Parking requirements by use are as follows: (1) Apartment or other multifamily dwelling: Two spaces for each dwelling unit. (2) Auditorium, stadium, assembly hall, gymnasium, theater, community recreation center, or church: Whichever of the following three standards is the greatest: a. One space per four fixed seats in largest assembly room or area; b. One space for each 40 square feet of floor area available for the accommodation of moveable seats, or combination of fixed and moveable seats, in the largest assembly room; or c. One space per each 150 square feet of gross floor area. (3) Automobile fueling station: Two spaces (in addition to service area) for each pump and grease rack, but not less than four spaces. (4) Automobile sales and repair, service station, carwash: Two spaces (in addition to service area) for each pump and grease rack, but not less than four spaces, plus one space for each 500 square feet of gross floor area of the shop or carwash. (5) Bowling alley: Four spaces per alley, plus requirements for any other use associated with the establishment such as a restaurant, etc. (6) Club or lodge: One space for each two employees, plus one space for each 200 square feet of gross floor area within the main assembly area, plus additional spaces for other uses permitted within the premises. (7) Combined uses: Parking spaces must be the total of the spaces required for each separate use established by this schedule. (8) Commercial recreation area (indoor or outdoor) such as YMCA or similar use: Whichever of the following two standards is the greatest: a. One space for each 150 square feet of gross floor, building or ground area; or b. One space for each four seats or facilities available for patron use. (9) Dance school: One space for each employee, plus one space per 150 square feet of gross floor area, plus adequate area for safe and convenient loading and unloading of students. (10) Dwelling (single-family or two-family): Two spaces for each dwelling unit. Residential driveways will satisfy this need. (11) Fraternity, sorority or college dormitory: One space for each two residents, plus one space for each two employees. (12) Golf course: Two spaces for each hole and one space for each two employees, plus requirements for any other use associated with the golf course. (13) Hospital, personal care home, intermediate care home or nursing home: One space for each three beds, plus one space for each two employees (nurses, attendants, etc.), plus one space for each staff or visiting doctor. (14) Hotel: One space for each three guestrooms, suites or units, plus one space for each two employees. (15) Kindergarten or nursery school: One space for each employee, plus adequate area for safe and convenient loading and unloading of students. (16) Manufacturing activity, industry or warehouse: Two spaces for each three employees on shift of greatest employment, plus one space for each vehicle used directly in the conduct of the business. (17) Motel: One space for each unit, plus one space for each two employees, plus requirements for any other use associated with the establishment such as a restaurant, etc. (18) Office, professional building or similar use: One space for each 300 square feet of gross floor area, plus one space for each two employees. (19) Personal service establishment: One space for each 200 square feet of gross floor area, but not less than two spaces for each employee. (20) Restaurant or place dispensing food, drink or refreshment: One space for each three seats, plus one space for each two employees on the shift of greatest employment. (21) Retail store of any type not otherwise specified in this schedule: One space per 200 square feet of gross floor area. (22) School (elementary): One space for each teacher, plus one space for each two employees and administrative personnel, plus one space for each classroom, plus adequate area for safe and convenient loading and unloading of students. (23) School (high, trade): One space for each two teachers, employees, administrative personnel, and student, plus adequate area for safe and convenient loading and unloading of students. (24) Shopping center: One space for every 200 square feet of gross floor area. (25) Swimming pool, public: One space for every 200 square feet of water surface, plus requirements for any other use associated with the establishment such as a restaurant, etc. (26) Wholesale establishment: One space for each employee, plus sufficient space, plus one space for each vehicle used directly in the conduct of the business. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(1), app. I, § 103) Sec. 66-79. - Number of loading spaces required. Manufacturing, industrial, wholesale and retail operations must provide loading space as follows: (1) Spaces appropriate to functions. Off-street loading spaces must be provided as appropriate to the functions and scope of operation or individual or groups of buildings and uses. (2) Design of loading spaces. Off-street loading spaces must be designed and constructed so that all maneuvering to park and unpark vehicles for loading can take place entirely within the property lines of the premises. Loading spaces must be provided so as not to interfere with the free, normal movement of vehicles and pedestrians on public rights-of-way. (3) Ingress and egress. Ingress and egress to off-street loading spaces must conform to curb cut requirements specified in this article. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(1), app. I, § 104) Sec. 66-80. - Curb cut requirements. In any case in which a provision for ingress and egress involves the lowering or cutting away of curbs, such a curb cut is subject to the following provisions: (1) Only one combined entrance and exit is allowed for any parcel of property with a frontage on any one street of less than 50 feet. No more than two combined entrances and exits are allowed for any parcel of property with a frontage on any one street of between 50 feet and 200 feet. For parcels of property having frontage on any one street of more than 200 feet, additional entrances or exits are permitted only after the developer demonstrates to the satisfaction of the planning commission that more curb cuts are needed for safety reasons, and such additional curb cuts are approved by the planning commission. (2) At street intersections, curb cuts must be located at least 25 feet from the intersections of the two curblines (or such lines extended) or at least 15 feet from the intersection of the two intersecting property lines (or such lines extended), whichever is less. (3) The distance between any two curb cuts on the same side of the street and located on one property must be at least ten feet. That distance is measured between the points at which the two curb cuts begin to deviate from the established curb line of the abutting street (in other words, between the intersections of the curb return radii and the established curbline of the abutting street). (4) The minimum setback from all property lines for any driveway is two feet. (5) The maximum permitted width of any driveway at the right-of-way line of the abutting street is 35 feet. (6) The maximum permitted width of any curb cut, including the points at which the curb cut begins to deviate from the established curbline of the abutting street at either end of the curb cut (in other words, including the curb returns) is 50 feet. However, the zoning administrator may approve a specified larger width for a truckstop, if he determines that a larger curb cut is needed for safety reasons. (7) The sum of the two curb return radii for any one curb cut must not exceed 15 feet. (Ord. of 3-16-1998(1), app. I, § 105) Chapters 67—69 - RESERVED

div.head: Chapter 70 - ROADS AND BRIDGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any resolution or ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the county saved from repeal, § 1-14(6); any resolution or ordinance providing for local improvement and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-14(9); any resolution or ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades of the county saved from repeal, § 1-14(15); buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; manufactured homes, ch. 54; planning, ch. 66; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 90; zoning ordinance, ch. 100; development ordinance, ch. 101; required development standards for streets, ch. 101, § 502. State Law reference— State, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 70-1—70-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ROAD USE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 70-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Heavily laden trucks, delivery vehicles, transport vehicles and pulpwood, logging or other timber cutting operations means all vehicles having a gross vehicle weight in excess of 26,001 pounds. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(1)) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 70-32. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person who pleads guilty, nolo contendere, or is convicted of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-19. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 5) Sec. 70-33. - Issuance of citation. The sheriff and deputies of the county, the road superintendent of the county and his designated representatives and the building inspector of the county are authorized to issue citations for the enforcement of this article as provided in O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-62 and 15-10-63. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 6.1) Sec. 70-34. - Stop work order. The sheriff and deputies of the county, the road superintendent of the county and his designated representatives and the building inspector of the county shall have the authority to temporarily stop/halt access to county roads at work site areas when they may deem the applicant to be in noncompliance of this article and until such time as the applicant brings the work site back into compliance. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, § 6.2) Secs. 70-35—70-55. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DELIVERY OR TRANSPORT VEHICLES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86.
Sec. 70-56. - Where possible, to use state routes, truck routes or major highway systems. All heavily laden trucks or delivery vehicles shall proceed over state routes, truck routes or major highway systems for the delivery of their goods where at all possible or feasible. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(1)(a)) Sec. 70-57. - Use of residential streets prohibited; exception. Such delivery or transport vehicles shall not proceed over residential paved streets and roads unless the use of such residential route is essential to their delivery. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(1)(b)) Sec. 70-58. - Use of unimproved road systems during rainy weather. Such delivery or transport vehicles shall not proceed over the county's unimproved road systems during periods of rain or inclement weather when such travel will cause excessive damage and maintenance to the road system or when the passage of smaller and lighter passenger vehicles will be substantially hampered. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(1)(c)) Sec. 70-59. - Crossing of bridges where load exceeds limits posted. Such heavily laden delivery and transport vehicles are restricted from crossing county bridges where their carted load exceeds the posted limit of the bridge. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(1)(d)) Secs. 70-60—70-80. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PULPWOOD, LOGGING OR OTHER TIMBER CUTTING OPERATIONS
Sec. 70-81. - Permit required for use of county maintained roads and crossing of county right-of-way ditches. All pulpwood, logging or other timber cutting operations which necessitate the use of county maintained roads and the crossing of county right-of-way ditches, shall, prior to commencement of such operation at any single work site, apply for and be issued a permit from the commissioners' office to use county roads and to cross right-of-way ditches at that work site. If such permit is granted, a copy shall be provided by the commissioner's office to the road department, county tax appraiser and tax commissioner. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(2)) Sec. 70-82. - Applicant to install culvert pipe and restore ditches after removal. The applicant shall install and bear the entire expense of an approved culvert pipe for the purpose of crossing the ditch. At the conclusion of the applicant's operations, the applicant shall return, and bear the expense of returning, the ditch to its original or better condition. The applicant is required to restore and shape the ditch, backslope and road bed and road shoulders to its original condition or better. The county shall inspect the ditch prior to installation and after the removal of the culvert pipe. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(2)(a)) Sec. 70-83. - Removal of trees, branches and limbs from roadsides and ditches. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to ensure all trees, branches and limbs are removed from county road sides and ditches so as to not restrict water flow or hamper the passage of county road department maintenance equipment, mowers, etc. This applies on both county unimproved road surfaces and county paved roadways. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(2)(b)) Sec. 70-84. - Removal of dirt or mud from road surfaces or rights-of-way. Dirt or mud brought onto the county road surfaces or county rights-of-way will be removed immediately so as to prevent the destruction of improved surfaces and so as to not impede or hamper safe motor vehicle operations over such surfaces. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to place enough stone pad surface at access points and/or to take sufficient preventive action to stop any dirt and mud from adhering to county roadways. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(2)(c)) Sec. 70-85. - Abatement by county upon failure to comply with division; billing of company. Should a pulpwood, logging or any other timber cutting company depart a work site without complying with sections 70-82, 70-83 or 70-84, then the county shall repair the damage, charge the cost of repair against the deposit required in section 70-87, and bill the company for any excess costs. No further permits shall be issued to that company until payment has been settled. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(2)(d)) Sec. 70-86. - Work site area defined. The work site area is considered to be the area at which contact is made with county roadways, ditches, right-of-way, roadway access points and access via county bridges. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(2)(e)) Sec. 70-87. - Permit application site; financial security required. (a) Permits shall be applied for at the commissioner's office in the courthouse. Upon approval of a permit, the applicant shall be required to establish financial security by posting a cash reserve deposit in favor of the county, which deposit shall be returned to the applicant upon full compliance with this article and after final inspection. (b) Financial security may be provided by the landowner, timber company, truck company or individual. (c) Financial security shall be $2,500.00 and applies regardless of the number of tracts harvested in the county so long as the financial security remains in effect. Otherwise, a valid replacement financial security must be obtained and delivered to the board of commissioners no later than the close of business of the fifth business day following the day that the board of commissioners filed a claim to recover damages against the then-existing financial security. (Ord. of 1-20-1998, art. 2(3); Ord. No. 2016-01-02, § 1, 1-11-2016) Secs. 70-88—70-120. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - UTILITY CONSTRUCTION ON PUBLIC ROADS[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 90.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 70-121. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Construction means any and all work involved with an incident to the construction, installation, maintenance, renewal, removal, repair and/or relocation of any utility facility. Highway, street or road means a general term denoting a public way for purposes of vehicular traffic, including the entire area within the right-of-way. Utility means all privately, publicly or cooperatively owned water distribution and sewer facilities and systems for producing, transmitting or distributing communication, cable television, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, steam, waste and stormwater. Utility facility means any and all wires, buried cable, conduit, pipe, pipe lines, casings and related fixtures. (Ord. of 4-3-1989, § 4.1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 70-122. - Enforcing officer. (a) Designated; purpose. The board of commissioners shall name, by appropriate resolution, an employee of the county to serve as their designated representative and agent for purposes of overseeing all matters concerning the enforcement of this article. (b) Authority; functions. Such designated representative shall have the authority to review permit applications, issue permits, inspect utility construction sites, require applicants to provide insurance and/or surety bond prior to commencing work, revoke or cancel permits, and to perform such other acts and functions as might be reasonably necessary in overseeing the enforcement of this article. (c) Citation issuance. Such designated representative shall be authorized to issue citations to violators of any provision of this article. Any such citation shall be on a form approved for such use by the board of commissioners and shall state the time and place at which the accused is to appear for trial, shall identify the offense with which he is charged and shall be signed by the representative of the person issuing such citation. (d) Trying of citations. Such citations shall be tried in the county magistrate court in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 15-10-1 et seq. (e) Civil actions. Nothing in this article shall prevent the board of commissioners or its designated representative from bringing any civil action for injunction, mandamus or other proceedings to present, correct or abate any violation of this article. No sanction, penalty or remedy prescribed in this article shall be considered exclusive of any other remedy, but shall be available in addition to any other sanction, penalty or remedy at law or equity. (f) Each violation a separate offense. Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. of 4-3-1989, § 6.0) Sec. 70-123. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person violating this article, or any provision of this article, upon conviction, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-19. (Ord. of 4-3-1989, § 6.1) Secs. 70-124—70-145. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PERMIT
Sec. 70-146. - Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, corporate entity, partnership, construction company, utility company or other legal entity to perform or cause to be performed any utility construction work involving the cutting and/or removal of or tunneling under any paved surface upon any public county road located in the unincorporated areas of the county without first securing a permit from the board of commissioners, or from its duly designated representative or agent. (Ord. of 4-3-1989, § 5.0) Sec. 70-147. - Commencement of construction not allowed prior to permit issuance. Any person, corporate entity, partnership, construction company, utility company or other legal entity desiring to perform any utility construction work involving or necessitating the cutting and/or removal of or tunneling under any paved surface upon any county road located in the unincorporated areas of the county must first apply for and obtain a written permit from the board of commissioners, or from its duly designated representative or agent and such utility construction shall not commence until such permit is secured. (Ord. of 4-3-1989, § 5.1) Sec. 70-148. - Issuance requirements; duration. (a) Generally. A separate permit shall be required for each construction project and involving or requiring the cutting and/or removal of or tunneling under any paved surface. Applications for such permit shall be made in writing to the board of commissioners or to its duly designated representative or agent. Such application shall include the following information: The name, address and phone number of the applicant; the identity of the road upon which construction permit is requested and the exact location thereon; a description of the nature and purpose of the construction and the method to be used in accomplishing the same; and the type or kind of utility for which the construction is proposed. All permits issued are governed by and subject to the provisions of subsections (b) and (c) of this section. (b) Work performance. (1) All utility construction permitted pursuant to this article must be performed and completed in accordance with all applicable requirements and provisions contained in certain rules and procedures promulgated and adopted by the state department of transportation and known as the "Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards, 1988," or the latest edition thereof. (2) The entire cost of any permitted utility construction pursuant to this article shall be paid by the applicant. (3) The applicant shall indemnify and hold harmless the county, its board of commissioners, the board's members, and all officers, employees or agents of the county against any and all damages, claims, demands, actions, costs and expenses of whatsoever nature, which may result from any injury to, or the death of, any persons or from the loss of, or damages to the property of any kind or nature, including the highway and highway facilities or structures, property or equipment used or owned by the county or the state or the state department of transportation, and facilities which now or may hereafter occupy the right-of-way of such highway, when such injury, death, loss or damages arises out of the construction, installation, maintenance, repair, removal, relocation, operation or use of any utility facility permitted pursuant to this article. (4) The county shall not be held responsible or liable for injury or damage that may occur to said utility facilities covered by the permit, or to any connection or connections thereto, by reason of highway maintenance, construction, repair or improvement activities on or near the permitted utility construction site. (5) The cutting and/or removal of any paved surface shall be permitted only when no reasonable alternative such as tunneling, boring, etc. is available to the applicant. When permitted, the cutting and/or removal of any paved surface shall be made in compliance with the "Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards," and the applicant shall further: a. Properly backfill and repave the highway at his expense; b. Be responsible for and pay for all construction and materials expense incurred in connection with such project and in connection with properly backfilling and repaving the surface; c. Pay and be responsible and liable for any and all expenses and costs of repair if the backfill subsides or the patched/repaired pavement fails; d. Cut or saw the paved surface in neat lines by methods approved by the board of commissioners or its duly designated representative or agent; e. Open only one-half of the paved surface at one time with the open half being completely backfilled before opening the other half; f. Promptly restore the paved surface in accordance with the specifications contained in "Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards"; and g. Clean up and properly dispose of all debris, refuse, etc., from the construction site. (6) The applicant shall employ any and all methods in performing the permitted utility construction reasonably necessary to properly protect the public from injury and the highway from damage. The applicant shall have sole responsibility for the adequacy and safety of the design and engineering of his facilities. (7) The board of commissioners or its duly designated representative or agent shall have the right to inspect the work performed pursuant to the permit and to require the applicant to promptly correct all deviations from the permit and from this article. (8) If the board of commissioners incurs any expense for correcting any deviations from the permit or from this article, the applicant shall pay and be responsible for such expenses. (9) Any contractor hired or employed by the applicant to perform the work for which the permit was granted shall agree in writing, prior to commencing the work, to perform such work in accordance with the terms of the permit and of this article; to indemnify and hold the county, its board of commissioners, such board's members, and all officers, employees or agents of the county from any injury or damage claims and from any additional expense incurred by the board of commissioners in correcting any deviations. (10) When requested in writing by the board of commissioners or its duly authorized representative or agent, the applicant and/or his contractor shall obtain and carry liability and property damage insurance in an amount to be determined by the board of commissioners or its duly authorized representative or agent and to present proof of such insurance prior to commencing the permitted work. (11) When requested in writing by the board of commissioners or its duly authorized representative or agent, the applicant and/or his contractor shall furnish a surety bond in an amount to be determined by the board of commissioners or its designated representative or agent, and no work shall be commenced until such bond is presented and approved by the board of commissioners or its agent or representative. (12) The applicant shall conduct the permitted utility construction in such a manner so that there will be a minimum of interference with or interruption of traffic upon and along the highway. The board of commissioners or its designated representative or agent is authorized to prohibit or restrict any work which may unduly interfere with traffic flow or interrupt the traffic flow during times of peak traffic flow. (13) Nothing in the permit issued or in this article shall be construed as relieving the applicant and/or its contractor from securing such other permits, licenses or other forms of approval from any other governmental agencies, utilities or railroads. (14) The applicant shall be responsible for giving appropriate notice of intended work to all landowners or utilities which might be impacted by the permitted utility construction. (c) Duration. (1) The permit shall be in effect for an indefinite period of time from and after the date issued, unless sooner revoked by mutual consent or by the board of commissioners or its designated representative or agent for the applicant's failure to abide by the terms and conditions of the permit and of this article. (2) The permit shall be deemed null and void if the permitted work is not commenced within 12 months from the date of its issuance. (3) The permit may be cancelled by the board of commissioners or by its duly designated representative or agent upon applicant's failing to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit or of this article after being given reasonable written notice of such noncompliance. (Ord. of 4-3-1989, § 5.2) Secs. 70-149—70-175. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PROTECTION OF PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY AND EASEMENTS[4]
