Sec. 90-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrator means the authority's general manager, or his or her designee, responsible for administration of the provisions of Water Capital Recovery Fees. Authority shall mean the members of the Butts County, City of Flovilla, City of Jackson, and City of Jenkinsburg Water and Sewer Authority and its agents and employees. Authority board means the board of directors of the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority. Board of commissioners means the Board of Commissioners of Butts County, Georgia. Building permit means the permit required for new construction pursuant to the Applicable Building Code. As used herein, the term shall not include permits required for remodeling, rehabilitation, or other improvements to an existing structure, provided there is no increase in the demand placed on public facilities, as such term is defined herein. Customer means any person, corporation, partnership, joint venture or public body that uses, has use of, has use for, or seeks to use the water system furnished by the authority. Capital improvement means an improvement with a useful life of ten (10) years or more, by new construction or other action, which increases the service capacity of a public facility. Capital improvement plan means that authority plan which sets out projected needs for water system improvements during a planning horizon established therein, which provides a schedule that will meet the anticipated need for system improvements, and which provides a description of anticipated funding sources for each required improvement. Capital recovery fee means a payment of money imposed upon and paid by new system customers as a condition of service approval to pay for a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements needed to serve new growth and development. County shall mean the members of the Board of Commissioners of Butts County, and its agents and employees. Developer means any person, corporation, partnership, joint venture, public body or legal entity that is selling, offering for sale, dividing, subdividing or developing property for residential, commercial or industrial use. Development activity means any construction or expansion of a building, structure, use, or any change in use of a building or structure, or any change in the use of land which results in a change in anticipated utility demands. Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others including such meaning as given under all applicable federal and state rules, regulations and statutes. Economic development means any development activity determined by the authority as extraordinary economic development. Encumber means to legally obligate by contract or otherwise commit to use by appropriation or other official act of the authority. Feepayer means that person who pays a Capital Recovery Fee, or his or her successor in interest, with the right or entitlement to any refund of a previously paid Capital Recovery Fee which is required by this ordinance and which has been expressly transferred or assigned to the successor in interest. In the absence of an express transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to any refund of previously paid Capital Recovery Fees, the right or entitlement shall be deemed "not to run with the land". Individual fee determination means a Capital Recovery Fee determined by the Administrator based on an Individual Fee Calculation Study. Individual fee calculation study means the documentation prepared by a Feepayer to allow determination of a Capital Recovery Fee other than by use of the fee schedule described in section 90-36.G.2b of this ordinance as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-4(g). May is permissive. Methodology report means the current approved technical report entitled "Water Capital Recovery Fee Report", as prepared under the direction of the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority. Owner means any individual, firm, company, partnership, corporation, institution, trust, organization, executor, or administrator owning property. Present value means the value, in present day dollars, of past, present or future payments, or contributions or dedications of goods, services, materials, construction, or money. Private development agreement means a mutual agreement between the authority and a developer regarding development activity which may include the project's proportionate share of system improvements being funded through a source other than Capital Recovery Fees. Project improvements mean site improvements and facilities that are planned and designed to provide service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience of the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements. The character of the improvement shall control a determination of whether an improvement is a project improvement or system improvement, and the physical location of the improvement on-site, or off-site, shall not be considered determinative of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement. If an improvement or facility provides, or will provide, more than incidental service or facilities capacity to persons other than users or occupants of a particular project, the improvement or facility is a System Improvement and shall not be considered a Project Improvement. Service area means a geographically defined area in which a defined set of public facilities provide, or are proposed to provide, service to existing, or future development. Shall is mandatory. Standard methods means the latest edition of the publication, Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, as published by the American Public Health Association, or such other equivalent testing methods as approved by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)or the Environmental Protection Division (EPD) of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. System improvements mean capital improvements which are designed to provide service to the community at large, in contrast to Project Improvements. System improvement costs mean costs incurred to provide public facilities capacity to serve new growth and development, including the costs of planning, design, engineering, construction, land acquisition, and land improvement for the construction or reconstruction of facility improvements or expansions. System improvement costs include the construction contract price, surveying and engineering fees, related land and easement acquisition costs (including land purchases, court awards and costs, attorneys' fees, and expert witness fees), and expenses incurred for qualified staff or any qualified engineer, planner, architect, landscape architect, or financial consultant for preparing or updating the capital improvements element and administrative costs of up to three (3) percent of the total of all other costs. Projected interest charges and other finance costs may be included if the impact fees are to be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes, or other financial obligations issued to finance system improvements, but such costs do not include routine and periodic maintenance expenditures, personnel training, and other operating costs. Water system means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, transporting, and disposing of sewage, and all appurtenances thereto. Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water, whether continuously or intermittently. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 90-32. - Application for new water service. (a) General. Any customer desiring to be provided with a new tap, or taps, for water service through the authority's water lines shall make an application for water services in person at the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority administrative offices in Jackson, Georgia. The owner of the property or structure to be served is responsible for the application. The total for connection to the water system shall be the sum of the Tap Fee or Meter Fee, AND the Capital Recovery Fee, and any required Security Deposit. (b) Application format. Applications for new water service shall include the following information and items: (a) a full and complete description of the project; (b) a full and complete description of the existing, or proposed, land use and development activity; (c) a statement as to whether the applicant seeks a certification of the Capital Recovery Fee Schedule or a certification of an Individual Fee Determination; and (d) if the applicant seeks a certification of an Individual Fee Determination, an Individual Fee Calculation Study complying with the requirements of section 90-36.g.2 shall be included. (c) Capital recovery fee certification. Upon application to the authority, any person may apply for and shall receive a certification of the Capital Recovery Fee Schedule or a certification of an Individual Fee Determination. (1) Timely provision of capital recovery fee schedule. The Administrator shall provide an applicant with a written certification of the Capital Recovery Fee Schedule within five (5) working days after receipt of a completed application. The fee schedule certified by the Administrator shall establish the Capital Recovery Fee Schedule for the proposed development activity for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of certification. (2) Certification of individual fee determination. The Administrator shall provide the applicant with a written certification of an Individual Fee Determination within thirty (30) days after receipt of a completed application. The Individual Fee Determination certified by the Administrator shall establish the Capital Recovery Fee for the proposed development activity for the one hundred eighty (180) day period immediately following the date of such certification. (3) Payment required prior to water tap agreement. Any persons required to pay Capital Recovery Fees pursuant to this ordinance shall pay such fees to the authority prior to the execution of an approved water tap agreement unless the authority has previously approved a Private Development Agreement providing for an alternative method of payment. (e) Line availability. If the water distribution system includes a water line adjacent to, or directly across the road from, the customer's property, and no water line extension is required, service will be provided upon the customer executing the Water Tap Agreement and paying the required fees as addressed in Sec. 90-36. Water service requiring a line extension is addressed in Sec. 90-41. (f) Installation list. Upon complying with the above stated items, the customer will be placed on the tap/meter installation list, and a work order issued for the connection. The connection will be installed by the authority, or its agent, as soon as practicable thereafter. Sec. 90-33. - Authority's responsibilities and liabilities. (a) Water connection line. Upon the customer meeting the requirements of Article II, the authority will run a water connection line to the property of the customer. The water connection will include a curb stop valve, meter, meter box. A pressure reducer may be installed on the authority's (street) side of the water meter at the discretion of the authority in those areas where average line pressure exceeds 90 psi. (b) Site of meter. The authority may install its meter at, or near, the property line, or at the authority's option, on the Customer's property within three (3) feet of the property line. (c) Initiation of service. When the customer has connected his/her piping to the meter, the authority will inspect the connection for a backflow prevention device and cut-off valve and turn on water service. Under no circumstances shall the customer operate the curb stop valve on the authority's (street) side of the meter. (d) Right to refuse service. The authority reserves the right to refuse service unless the customer's lines and piping are installed in keeping with the authority's specifications and the regulations of the current plumbing code in Butts County. (e) Interruptions of service. Under normal conditions, the customer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the authority. Sec. 90-34. - Consumer's responsibilities and liabilities. (a) Water use. Water furnished by the authority shall be used for consumption by the customer, members of the household, employees and/or visitors only. The customer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. The customer shall not allow anyone else to connect onto the water system serving the customer. Water shall not be used for irrigation, or other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interference with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard of this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or discontinuance of service. (b) Access to meter. Where the meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a customer, a suitable place shall be provided by the customer therefor, which is unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. (c) Customer's cut-off valve. The customer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the customer's side of the meter within, or immediately adjacent to, the meter box. (d) Backflow prevention device. The customer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the customer at the customer's expense so as to prevent a backflow by use of an approved backflow prevention device. This device should meet the specifications of the authority and in most circumstances may be purchased directly from the authority. Under normal conditions, the backflow prevention device must be located within, or immediately adjacent to, the meter box. (e) Pressure relief device. The customer shall furnish and maintain an approved pressure relief device on a cold water line on the customer's side of the meter according to the requirements of the adopted plumbing code in Butts County. (f) Pressure regulation. It is the customer's responsibility to furnish and maintain any device necessary to adjust pressure from the authority's lines to protect the customer's private water lines and appurtenances. (g) Disconnection of wells. (1) No physical connection. In order to be received as a customer and entitled to receive water from the authority's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the authority's water system. All applicants, by becoming customers of the authority, covenant and agree that, so long as they continue to be customers of the authority, they will not permit the connection of any private wells to the authority's water system. (2) Sealing of certain wells. Where water service is available and continued use of a well is determined to pose a health risk by an Environmental Health Specialist of the Butts County Health Department, all affected property owners must connect to the authority's system. In areas designated on an individual lot by lot basis, all existing wells must be disconnected, filled, sealed and plugged from further use, in accordance with the Georgia Department of Natural Resources and Butts County Board of Health regulations, and no new wells may be bored or drilled. (h) Requirement to connect. For new construction, the water distribution system of any building in which plumbing fixtures are installed shall be connected to the authority's lines if the building is within two hundred feet (200') of a water main. Sec. 90-35. - Access to consumer's premises by agents and employees of the authority. Duly authorized agents and employees of the authority shall have access at all hours to the premises of the customer and/or property owner for the purposes of installing and removing the property of the authority, inspecting the authority's facilities, reading and testing meters, and repairing and maintaining the facilities of the authority. Sec. 90-36. - Fees for water service. (a) Water rates. The rate schedule for water use is set by the authority from time to time. The current rate for water use is shown in Appendix C. However, water rates will not increase without thirty (30) days notice to the customer. Notice will be sufficiently given to the customer by a publication of the rate changes at least two (2) times in consecutive weeks in the official newspaper of Butts County prior to the rate increase. (b) Minimum charge. All customers who pay a connection fee to the authority will be required to pay the minimum monthly charge as set by the authority commencing on the next billing date after the meter is set and water is available for consumption. Customers who are not using water may have their meter declared inactive to avoid payment of the minimum charge each month, but will be required to pay a re-activation fee as per section 90-37.b.2 to begin using water again. (c) Deposits. (1) Setting of deposit fees. The authority is authorized to establish security deposit fees to be paid for water and sewer service and to collect such fees upon application for service and at such other times as the authority may determine to be necessary. Notice will be sufficiently given to the customer by a publication of deposit fee changes at least two (2) times in consecutive weeks in the official newspaper of Butts County prior to the increase. (2) Refund of deposits. When a customer moves out of a property, the deposit, less any amount owed, will be refunded to the customer. Also, individual security deposits are also refunded to customers with an excellent payment history after 24 months on the system. Payment history is considered excellent if the customer has had no more than one late penalty during the 24 months. If the customer receives a second late payment penalty during this time frame, the 24 month period will begin again from the date of the last penalty. No interest will apply. (3) Exemption from deposit. Customers who have been on the authority's system for 24 months or longer, and who have excellent payment history, may be exempted from paying a security deposit if moving from one address to another, or if adding another unit to the system. (4) Requirement of deposit from landlords under certain circumstances. When rental property service is in the name of the renter and if: a. the property is vacated, b. a new tenant does not immediately move in, and c. the service is shut off at the meter, the property owner will be responsible for the minimum monthly bill, but will not be required to make a deposit. If service is not shut off at the meter, a regular deposit will be required from the property owner. (d) Tap fees. Tap fees are applied when a new tap must be made in the water main to make the service connection. Tap fees are set by the authority and charged according to the schedule shown in Appendix B. (e) Meter fees. Meter fees are applied in developments where the developer has previously installed water taps and only a meter installation is required to make the service connection. Meter fees are set by the authority and charged according to the schedule shown in Appendix B. (f) Payment plans. In cases of extreme financial hardship, the authority manager may give approval for a customer to pay required connection fees over time. The customer must provide documentation of financial need. The maximum extension allowed will be twenty-five percent down with the balance paid in equal payments over six months. (g) Capital recovery fees. Any person or corporation who ties onto the water system's established service area shall pay a Capital Recovery Fee in the manner and amount established by this ordinance. In all cases, the Capital Recovery Fee must be paid prior to authorization of connection to the water system area in the form of an executed Tap Agreement. (1) Computation of capital recovery fee. The capital recovery fee assessment shall be in accordance with the fee schedule shown in Appendix A or as otherwise established pursuant to applicable procedures of this ordinance. Any Capital Recovery Fee imposed shall not exceed a project's proportionate share of the cost of system improvements, shall be calculated on the basis of the establishment of service areas, and shall be calculated on the basis of levels of service for public facilities that are the same for existing development as for new growth and development. (2) Individual fee determination a. Petition allowed. An applicant for development approval may petition the authority for an individual fee determination of Capital Recovery Fees due for a project. b. Individual fee calculation study. An applicant electing an individual fee determination shall submit an Individual Fee Calculation Study for the development activity for which service is sought. The Individual Fee Calculation Study shall follow the methodology and format of the current "Water Capital Recovery Fee Report" or, subject to prior approval of the Administrator, such other professionally accepted methodology that identifies a project's proportionate share. The applicant shall attend a pre-application meeting with the Administrator, and no agreement or understanding in regard to data assumptions or methodology shall be binding upon the authority unless specifically agreed to by the authority in writing. The documentation submitted shall show the basis upon which the Individual Fee Calculation was made. c. Determination time frame. The Administrator shall provide the applicant with the Individual Fee Determination within thirty (30) days after presentation of the Individual Fee Calculation Study. (3) Changes to proposed development. Not withstanding the issuance of any such certification, any changes in or additions to the proposed development activity different from the development activity identified in the original application shall be subject to increased or additional Capital Recovery Fees to the extent that such changes or additions would have resulted in the determination of a different fee than that assessed from the original application. The additional Capital Recovery Fees shall be based upon the Capital Recovery Fee Schedule in effect at the time of any such change or addition. (4) Payment of capital recovery fees. a. Payment required prior to water tap/meter agreement. Any persons required to pay Capital Recovery Fees pursuant to this ordinance shall pay such fees to the authority prior to the issuance of an approved water tap/meter agreement unless the authority has previously approved a Private Development Agreement providing for an alternative method of payment. b. Additional payment required due to alteration or expansion. Any persons who engage in an alteration or expansion of an existing building or use of land already on the water system, which results in an additional water demand will be required to pay additional assessed Capital Recovery Fees prior to the issuance of a building permit. c. Fees to be deposited into trust fund. All funds collected pursuant to this ordinance shall be properly identified by the Capital Recovery Fee Service Area from which it was collected and promptly transferred for deposit into the appropriate Capital Recovery Fee Trust Fund to be held in separate accounts as provided for in Sec. 90-36.g.10 (Capital Recovery Fee Trust Funds Established) of this ordinance. Funds shall be used solely for the purposes specified in this ordinance. (5) Use of funds. a. Funds to be used for system improvements. Funds collected as Capital Recovery Fees shall be used for System Improvements. No funds shall be used for periodic or routine maintenance or for any purpose not in accordance with the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-71-8. Capital Recovery Fees shall be used exclusively for System Improvements in the Service Area in which the project for which the fees were paid is located. Funds shall be expended in the order in which they are collected. b. Annual report required. Each fiscal year, the authority's general manager shall present to the authority's board of directors an annual report describing the amount of Capital Recovery Fees collected, encumbered and used during the preceding year. Monies, including any accrued interest, not encumbered in any fiscal year shall be retained in the same Capital Recovery Fee Trust Fund(s) until the next fiscal year except as provided in § 90-36.g.8 (Refunds) of this ordinance. c. Administrative fee. The authority shall be entitled to retain up to three percent (3%) of all Capital Recovery Fees it collects as an administrative fee to offset the costs of administering this ordinance. d. Fees may be used for debt service. Capital Recovery Fees may be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes or other financial obligations issued by or on behalf of the authority to finance system improvements. (6) Credits. a. Project improvements. No credit shall be given for Project Improvements. b. System improvements. Credit shall be given for the Present Value of the construction of improvements or contribution or dedication of land or money by a developer or his predecessor in title for System Improvements accepted by the authority in accordance with a Private Development Agreement. 1. A person claiming Credits under a Private Development Agreement shall submit to the Administrator a project description in sufficient detail to allow the Administrator to prepare an engineering and construction cost estimate. A person proposing credit for system improvements shall present cost estimates and property appraisals prepared by duly licensed and qualified professionals to be used by the Administrator in determining the amount of the credit. All construction must be carried out in accordance with applicable authority, county, or state development and design standards. A person seeking Credits under a Private Development Agreement for land dedication shall present the Administrator with property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals and a certified copy of the most recent assessment of the property for tax purposes. However, the authority retains the right to determine the amount to be credited by preparing engineering and construction cost estimates and/or property appraisals for those improvements. 2. Credits must be claimed at the time of the application for water service. Any credit not so claimed shall not be available as to any Capital Recovery Fee owed with respect to water service to that particular property. 3. In the event that a developer contracts with the authority to construct, fund, or contribute System Improvements so that the amount of the Credit created by such construction, funding or contribution is in excess of a particular Capital Recovery Fee which would have been otherwise due and owing, the developer shall be reimbursed for such excess contribution, funding, or contribution from the pool of Capital Recovery Fees paid by the development projects located in the service area which benefit by such improvements. 4. Security in the form of a performance bond, or escrow agreement shall be posted with the authority, made payable to the authority in the amount approved by the Administrator equal to one hundred ten percent (110%) of the full cost of the construction of such improvements. If a facility construction project will not be constructed within one (1) year of acceptance of the offer by the authority, the amount of the security shall be increased by ten percent (10%) compounded, for each year of the life of the security. The security shall be reviewed and approved by the authority's attorney prior to the acceptance of the security by the authority. c. Credit certificate. Credits shall be represented by a written certificate (the "Credit Certificate") setting forth the name of the person or entity to whom the Credit certificate is issued, the number of the Credit Certificate, and the amount of the credit. The authority shall also maintain a register (the "Credit Certificate Register") which shall set forth the name of the credit holder, the number of the Credit Certificate, and the amount of the credit. (7) Exemptions. a. Exempt development types. The following shall be exempted from the payment of Capital Recovery Fees: 1. Alteration or expansion of an existing building or use of land where no additional living units are created, where the use is not changed, and where the Administrator determines that no additional demand will result. 2. The construction of accessory buildings or structures which will not result in additional demand as determined by the Administrator. 3. The replacement of a building or structure that was in place on the effective date of this ordinance, or the replacement of a building or structure that was constructed subsequent thereto and for which the correct Capital Recovery Fee had been paid or otherwise provided for, with a new building or structure of the same use, provided that no additional demand will result as determined by the Administrator. b. Documentation required for exemption. A person claiming exemptions(s) pursuant to section 90-36.g.7a above shall submit to the Administrator information and documentation sufficient to permit the Administrator to determine whether such exemption claimed is proper, and, if so, the extent of such exemption. c. Time for exemption application. Exemptions must be applied for at the time of the application for a building permit except in the case of a private development agreement. Any exemptions not so applied for shall be deemed waived. (8) Refunds. Refunds of impact fees shall be made only in the following instances and in the following manner: a. Capacity available but service denied. Upon application to the Administrator by the Feepayer, the authority shall refund ninety-seven percent (97%) of the Capital Recovery Fee if capacity is available and service is denied. The authority shall retain three percent (3%) of the fee paid as an administrative fee. b. Failure to encumber or expend fee when service is not available. 1. Upon application to the Administrator by the Feepayer, the authority shall refund ninety-seven percent (97%) of the Capital Recovery Fee paid and not expended or encumbered if the authority, after collecting the fee when service is not available, has failed to encumber the fee or commence construction within six (6) years from the date the Capital Recovery Fee was paid. The authority shall retain three percent (3%) of the fee paid as an administrative fee. In determining whether capital Recovery Fees have been expended or encumbered, fees shall be considered encumbered on a first-in, first-out (FIFO) basis. 2. When the right to a refund exists due to a failure to encumber Capital Recovery Fees, the authority shall provided written notice of entitlement to a refund to the Feepayer who paid the Capital Recovery Fee at the address shown on the application for development approval, or to a Feepayer's successor in interest who has give the authority notice of the transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to a refund and who has provided the authority a mailing address. The authority shall also publish such notice within thirty (30) days of the expiration of the six (6) year period after the date the capital Recovery Fee was paid. The published notice shall contain the heading "Notice of Entitlement to Capital Recovery Fee Refund". c. Refund application due within one year. A refund application shall be made to the Administrator within one (1) year from the date such refund becomes payable under paragraphs A and B of this section or within one (1) year from the date of publication of the Notice of Entitlement of a Refund under paragraph (b) of this section, whichever is later. Any refund not applied for within said time period shall be deemed waived. d. Refund documentation required. A refund application shall include information and documentation sufficient to permit the Administrator to determine whether the refund claimed is proper, and if so, the amount of such refund. e. Accrued Interest to Be Applied. A refund shall include a pro rata share of interest actually earned on the unused or excess impact fee paid. f. Time period for refunds. All refunds shall be paid within sixty (60) days after the Administrator determines that such refund is due. (9) Water capital recovery fee service area established. The water system service area consists of all areas of unincorporated Butts County served by the authority. This includes: (1) properties along roadways currently served by the authority's system and (2) any new subdivisions and commercial/industrial developments to be served by connection to the authority's system with new county or private roads. The area does not include properties served by existing county roads that do not have access to water service. However, once water service from the authority has been available for connection on any of those roads for a period of thirty days, said roads will be included in the service area. The service area is expected to expand in the future to include any and all additional area served by the water system, with no separate service areas anticipated to be established. (10) Water capital recovery fee trust fund established. a. Establishment. There is hereby established a Water Capital Recovery Fee Trust Fund. b. Funds shall be interest bearing. Capital Recovery Fees shall be deposited and maintained in one or more interest bearing accounts. Interest earned on Capital Recovery Fees shall be funds of the account on which it is earned and subject to all restrictions imposed by section 6.4 (Use of Funds) of this ordinance. (11) Review of fee structure. The Capital Recovery Fee structure shall be reviewed by the authority's board of directors annually. The failure to review such structure shall not invalidate this ordinance. (12) Administrative appeals. a. Appealable items. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the Administrator with respect to any of the following determinations shall have the right to appeal to the authority's board of directors: (a) the imposition of a Capital Recovery Fee, (b) the amount of a Capital Recovery Fee, (c) the entitlement to and/or the amount of credits to a Capital Recovery Fee, (d) the entitlement to an exemption from a Capital Recovery Fee, and (e) the entitlement to and/or the amount of a refund of a Capital Recovery Fee. Prior to any appeal to the authority's board of directors, the aggrieved party shall file a request for reconsideration with the Administrator, who shall act upon the request within thirty (30) days. b. Timetable for hearing appeals. All appeals shall be taken within thirty (30) days of the Administrator's decision on the request for reconsideration by filing with the Administrator a notice of appeal specifying the grounds therefor. The authority's board of directors shall establish a date and time for a hearing on the appeal, give due notice thereof to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable period of time following the hearing. Any party taking an appeal shall have the right to appear at the hearing to present evidence and may be represented by counsel. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the authority's board of directors may take an appeal to the Superior Court of Butts County within thirty (30) days after the decision of the authority is rendered. c. Payment under protest. A person may pay a Capital Recovery Fee under protest to obtain an approved water tap agreement, and by making such payment shall not be stopped from (a) exercising the right of appeal provided in this section or (b) receiving a refund of any amount as a result of such appeal. Sec. 90-37. - Meter designations and readings. (a) Reading schedule. The water meter serving the customer's property shall be read on a monthly basis and official records of each reading thereof shall be kept for a minimum period of one (1) year. (b) Meter designation. Water meters shall be classified as either "active meters", "inactive meters", and "canceled meters". These designations are defined as follows: (1) Active meters. "Active meters" are defined as meters that are in normal use. All active meters will be charged on a monthly basis. (2) Inactive meters. "Inactive meters" are defined as meters that are installed where the customer has notified the authority in writing to temporarily terminate service. When it receives such written request, the authority will seal the meter and declare the meter an inactive meter. When no responsible party is available to request inactive meter designation for the customer, the authority may declare the meter inactive. If a customer desires to obtain water services after the meter has been declared inactive, the customer shall pay a re-connection fee as set in the prevailing fee schedule of the authority. In addition, the customer must pay any previous unpaid bills which that customer had through the authority's services prior to obtaining any additional service from the authority. Once the connection fee and any past due bills have been paid, the meter will be re-classified as an active meter as defined above. (3) Canceled meters. Canceled meters are defined as meters that have not been in use where the customer has notified the authority that no further water service from the authority is desired. The authority may, on its own initiative, declare a meter canceled when water has not been used for a period of twelve (12) months or longer. If a meter is declared a canceled meter, the meter will be removed and the connection sealed. A customer desiring re-connection of a canceled meter shall pay the capital recovery fee, meter fee, and security deposit that is in effect as of the date of application. Sec. 90-38. - Billings and collections. (a) Payment. The customer shall pay promptly on a monthly basis all water registered by the meter serving said property at the rates set by the authority from time to time, which shall include water used, water wasted, or leakage, except for the water that may be traced by the authority to the authority's system. Property owners shall be responsible for any unpaid water bills left by tenants. (b) Billing Schedule. The authority is authorized to establish billing schedules for payment of water and sewer service. (c) Billing errors. If the customer believes his/her bill to be in error, this claim must be presented to the authority, or its billing agent, before the bill becomes due. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The customer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his claim. Any customer who fails to notify the authority in writing within 30 days after the date of said bill of any irregularities or errors that may be in said bill shall waive any right or claim for correction or refund under said bill. (d) Meter failure. If the seal of a meter is broken by any person other than the authority's representative, or if the meter fails to register correctly, or is stopped for any cause, the customer shall pay an amount which is the average for the three (3) previous months water usage. (e) Meter testing. The authority will carry out a regular program of meter testing and replacement. In addition, water meters will be tested at the request of the customer. If the meter is found to be reading at a higher rate than actual flow, no charge will be made. However, if the meter is found to be reading at 101.5% or less, the customer will be required to pay a service fee to be set by the authority. (f) Meter reading re-checks. The authority may establish and charge a fee for meter reading re-checks except that no fee will be charged for re-checks requested by the customer when the original reading shown appears to have been incorrect. (g) Credit for excessive leakages. In cases where water is shown to have leaked through a customer's private water piping and has caused billing which is over 20,000 in excess of that customer's average monthly usage over the previous twelve months, the customer will be required to pay only the authority's current cost of water plant operation per 1000 gallons for said usage over 20,000 gallons over the average. In cases of extremely high bills due to such leaks, the authority manager may set up a payment schedule for the customer. (h) Returned check fee. Customers who make payments with checks which are not covered by sufficient funds will be charged a "returned check fee" as set by the authority. When a customer has written two (2) checks which have been returned for insufficient funds, the authority will accept only cash or money orders for future payment as long as the account remains in that customer's name. This is regardless of who makes the payment on the account. (i) Water bill payment extensions. Customers will be allowed a maximum of two time extensions per year for payment of water bill. This applies to late payment penalties, warning fees, and reconnect fees. In Witness Whereof, the partners hereto, acting under the authority of their respective governing bodies, have caused this Contract to be duly executed in two (2) counterparts, each of which shall constitute an original. Sec. 90-39. - Suspension of services. (a) Termination with notice. Service may be terminated at the request of the customer. Service may also be terminated for nonpayment of water and/or sewer charges according to the adopted policies of the authority. In such cases, the authority will attempt to notify the customer of the impending service termination in advance to allow for a settling of accounts prior to the termination. (b) Termination without notice. The authority reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following reasons: (1) Prevention of fraud or abuse; (2) Customer's willful disregard of the authority's adopted policies; (3) Emergency repairs; (4) Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the authority's control; (5) Legal processes; (6) Direction of public authorities; and (7) Strike, riot, fire, flood, unavoidable accident, actions of others, or acts of God. (c) Other terminations. The authority reserves the right to terminate the services granted by the authority for any other reason other than those stated above by giving the customer ten (10) days written notice of the date of termination, and further providing the customer with a right to hearing prior to termination of the service. Sec. 90-40. - Allocation of water services. The authority shall have the right from time to time, if necessary, to restrict water to the customer under specific rules and regulations that are contained in its Water Conservation Plan and Drought Contingency Plan, or that may be adopter hereafter by the authority. The authority shall also restrict water to the customer under the direction and rules of the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. Sec. 90-41. - Line extensions. (a) authority's responsibility for line extension. When public funds are available for line extensions, the authority will carry out construction in the order established in a priority road list adopted by the authority. This list shall be based upon a balance of sound engineering and service to a maximum customer base. A current road priority list for line extensions on roads unincorporated Butts County shall be maintained by the authority and made available to the public. (b) Plans and specifications for construction of water lines. The authority shall have the right to specify the requirements, plans, and specifications for construction of water lines in unincorporated Butts County. All water lines constructed, or paid for, by the authority, any municipality, utility, contractor, consumer, owner, or developer shall be constructed according to the plans and specifications established by the authority for the construction of water lines in Butts County. No water line shall be covered without first being inspected and approved by the authority. No line shall be put into service without being approved by the authority for disinfection and pressure tightness. (c) Extensions not initiated by the authority. (1) Water line extensions to existing residential, industrial, and commercial development. The authority recognizes that areas of pre-existing development may have property owners who desire water service prior to public funds being available for construction. Therefore, on existing public roads, the authority will provide labor and equipment at no charge for line extensions to existing development under the following conditions: a. Right-of-way. Water lines may only be extended along county roads which have sufficient dedicated right-of-way. b. Payment for design, materials, blasting. The customer will be required to pay to the authority, prior to the commencement of construction, an amount sufficient to pay for all costs associated with design and materials that are required to build the proposed line and to extend the authority's water main from the existing water main which has sufficient size to service the proposed line. The cost of the project will be determined by the authority. The authority will provide an initial estimate of cost to the interested parties at no charge. It is immaterial whether the costs for the line are shared equally by the customers or whether one or more property owners or customers pays for the water line extension. In the event that it becomes apparent to the authority that construction of said line will cost more than the original estimated cost, the authority may terminate work until such time as adequate funds have been placed with the authority. (2) Authority consideration. The authority's board of directors will consider an application from an existing development, or group of owners of existing development, when the following are provided: a. Documentation of sufficient right of way and/or easements as required by the county and the authority. b. A petition of property owners to be served with the signature of all participants, the number of connections to be made for each participant, and an indication of the cost to be borne by each participant. c. Deposit of the estimated funds for design, materials, and any anticipated blasting. d. Deposit of the required connection fees for individual customers. If the request is approved by the authority board, an estimated date of completion will be given to the customer, but a date of completion cannot be guaranteed because of changes in work schedule, weather conditions, equipment breakdown, delays in delivery of materials, improvement of the right of way, or other unpredictable circumstances. (3) Ownership of lines. All water lines built will become the property of the authority. (4) Unused funds. Any unused funds provided by the property owners for line construction will be reimbursed by the authority upon completion of construction. (d) Water line extensions to serve new residential, commercial, and industrial development. (1) Developer responsible for all costs of extension. This section applies inside new residential subdivisions, industrial sites, and commercial sites and to necessary extensions along existing public roads to reach those sites. The owner of any new development will be required to pay for labor, materials, design and all other costs of water line extension. At the option of the authority, construction of extensions to and within new development may be done by the authority or by a qualified contractor working for the developer. In any case, line construction must adhere strictly to adopted authority specifications. (2) Authority consideration. Extensions to new development will be considered under the following conditions: a. Sufficient dedicated right-of-way must be available along public roads required to access the development. b. The developer must provide a letter from the Butts County Community Services Department that the property has been approved for the proposed use according to the zoning and development regulations of Butts County. c. The developer must provide the authority with three (3) copies of a plat or accurate drawing of the property to be served at a format and scale that meets the authority's specifications. Said plats or drawings shall contain the following information: 1. Location of the closest existing water line of the authority which is of sufficient size to serve the property; 2. Location of the existing and proposed roads to serve the property; 3. Exact size, material, and footage of water line that will have to be installed in order to serve the property; 4. Location of all water lines and appurtenances to be constructed in the area to be developed; and 5. Documentation that lines and appurtenances have been sized to meet the specifications the county and the authority for customer demand and fire flows. d. The developer must document financial ability to pay the cost of construction. If the construction will be provided by the authority, the total cost of the project, as estimated by the authority, must be paid to the authority. A letter of credit signed by the president of an accredited bank in the State of Georgia will be acceptable in lieu of cash. In the event that it becomes apparent to the authority that construction of said lines will cost more than the original estimated cost, the authority may terminate work until such time as adequate funds have been placed with the authority, or a revised letter of credit with an adequate figure is received. (3) Construction by authority. Water lines will only be placed within easements established for such purposes, or within right of way lines of streets and roads which have been certified as being part of the public road system of Butts County. An estimated date of completion cannot be guaranteed because of changes in work schedule, weather conditions, equipment breakdown, delays in delivery of materials, improvement of the right of way, or other unpredictable circumstances. All water lines built are the property of the authority. Any unused funds deposited by the Developer for the line construction will be reimbursed by the authority upon commencement of water services. (4) Construction by developer. Lines will normally be allowed to be constructed by the Developer only within the development itself. During construction, the authority will inspect work as necessary. Upon completion of construction by the developer, but prior to the initiation of water service the following must be done: a. The authority will conduct tests to ensure that completed water lines meet authority specifications for pressure, flow and water quality. b. The developer must post a deed conveying the water line, appurtenances thereto, and any required permanent easements to the authority. c. The developer must post a surety bond, or a letter of credit from any banking institution within the State of Georgia, with the authority in the amount of ten percent (10%) of the total cost of the construction of said line, which said bond, or letter of credit, shall guarantee payment to the authority for any repairs or maintenance needed in said line over a period of one (1) year from the date of conveyance of said line. The authority will conduct a final comprehensive inspection of the water infrastructure once the facility has been in service between eleven (11) and twelve (12) months. The developer will be responsible for any corrections and listed noted through that time. d. The developer must furnish three (3) copies of as-built water lines and appurtenances in the size and format specified by the authority. e. The developer must execute an affidavit prescribed by the authority stating that the cost of all labor and materials has been paid accompanied by copies of all invoices. (e) Construction by municipalities or other water utilities in unincorporated Butts County. (1) Approval. Water line construction by municipalities or other water utilities within unincorporated Butts County must adhere strictly to adopted authority specifications and must be approved by the authority's board of directors prior to construction. In cases of such extensions, the developer of said extensions must provide the authority with three (3) copies of a plat or accurate drawing of the property to be served. Said plats or drawings shall contain the following information: a. Location of the closest existing water line of the authority which is of sufficient size to serve the property; b. Location of the existing and proposed roads to serve the property; c. Exact size, material, and footage of water line that will have to be installed in order to serve the property; d. Location of all water lines and appurtenances to be constructed in the area to be developed; and e. Documentation that lines and appurtenances have been sized to meet the specifications the county and the authority for customer demand and fire flows. The authority is authorized to assess a fee for plan approval. (2) As-Built documentation. Upon completion of construction, but prior to the initiation of water service, documentation that the extension has been tested for pressure, flow, and water quality must be provided to the authority. The municipality installing water infrastructure in unincorporated Butts County must furnish three (3) copies of as-built water lines and appurtenances in the size and format specified by the authority. (f) Permit from Butts County board of commissioners. A permit, or easement, from the Butts County Board of Commissioners is required for water line installation along county rights of way. Said permit, or easement, may be granted for such installation only after approval of construction plans by the authority. Sec. 90-42. - Prohibition against tampering with authority and county property and providing punishment therefor. (a) Prohibited actions. Any customer, person, firm or corporation that without the authorization of the authority: (1) Connects onto a water line of the authority; (2) Disconnects a water line from a water line of the authority; (3) Connects onto a water meter of the authority; (4) Disconnects a water meter of the authority; (5) Moves, removes, changes, or alters the location of a water meter; (6) Changes, alters, or damages any water meter or water line so as to prevent proper registration of water passing through said water meter or line; (7) Obtains water; (8) Prevents any other person from obtaining water; (9) Obstructs, or otherwise interferes, with the reading or maintenance of any water meter; (10) Obstructs or otherwise interferes with any water line, fire hydrant, pumping station, or any appurtenances to water facilities of Butts County; (11) Creates a hazardous or unsafe condition to the water facilities of Butts County; or (12) Constructs and/or initiates service to a water line without approval of plans, specifications, and installation by the authority; shall be issued a citation, and if found guilty, shall be subject to a minimum fine of $250.00 to a maximum fine of $1000.00 plus damages and/or imprisonment in the county jail of Butts County for a minimum of 30 days to a maximum of 60 days. (b) Court of jurisdiction. The Magistrate Court of Butts County, Georgia, shall have jurisdiction to hear, try, and dispose of citations that are issued for said violations. (c) Issuance of citation. All customers, persons, firms, or corporations who are charged with having violated this ordinance shall be issued a citation by employees designated by the board of directors of the Butts County, et al Water and Sewer authority, the Butts County Code Enforcement Officer, or any certified peace officer having jurisdiction within Butts County. Said citation shall require the appearance of the violator in the Magistrate Court of Butts County, Georgia to any said charges. (Amended March 7, 2005) (d) Reward for information. The authority will may pay a reward for any information leading the issuance of a citation and conviction of any customer, person, firm, or corporation found to have engaged in any of the prohibited actions listed above. The amount of reward will be set by the authority. Sec. 90-43. - Fire hydrant water use. The authority may allow sale of bulk water through its fire hydrants under such policies and regulations as it may see fit to adopt. Sec. 90-44. - Enforcement of ordinance. The authority shall enforce the terms of this ordinance through the administrative procedures hereinbefore set out through legal actions in a court of law. Sec. 90-45. - Amendment to ordinance. This ordinance may be amended through vote of both the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer authority and the Butts County Board of Commissioners. Notice of the proposed amendment must be advertised at least one time in the legal newspaper of Butts County at least fifteen (15) days prior to final vote on adoption of any such amendment. Sec. 90-46. - Repealer. All ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. Secs. 90-47—90-49. - Reserved. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[4]

Sec. 90-50. - Objectives. The objectives of this article are: (1) To prevent the introduction of pollutants that will interfere with the operation of the authority's sewer system or otherwise contaminate the natural environment. (2) To prevent the introduction of inadequately treated pollutants which will pass through either the authority's sewer system or natural environment, thereby polluting receiving waters, lands, or the atmosphere, or otherwise be incompatible with the authority's sewage treatment system. (3) To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the system. (4) To provide for equitable distribution of the cost of the authority's sewer system. (5) To maintain compliance with the laws and regulations of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and Butts County. (Ord. of 11-17-2014, § 1(Exh. A)) Sec. 90-51. - [Definitions.] The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrator means the authority's general manager, or his or her designee, responsible for administration of the provisions of Sewerage Capital Recovery Fees. Authority Board means the board of directors of the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority. Board of Commissioners means the Board of Commissioners of Butts County, Georgia. Building Permit means the permit required for new construction pursuant to the Applicable Building Code. As used herein, the term shall not include permits required for remodeling, rehabilitation, or other improvements to an existing structure, provided there is no increase in the demand placed on public facilities, as such term is defined herein. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called "house connection." Capital Improvement means an improvement with a useful life of ten (10) years or more, by new construction or other action, which increases the service capacity of a public facility. Capital Improvement Plan means that portion of the Butts County Comprehensive Plan which sets out projected needs for sewer system improvements during a planning horizon established therein, which provides a schedule that will meet the anticipated need for system improvements, and which provides a description of anticipated funding sources for each required improvement. Capital Recovery Fee means a payment of money imposed upon and paid by new system customers as a condition of service approval to pay for a proportionate share of the cost of system improvements needed to serve new growth and development. Customer means any person, corporation, partnership, joint venture or public body that uses, has use of, has use for, or seeks to use the sewer system furnished by the authority. Decentralized Sewer System means any sewer system capable of collecting, pumping, treating, transporting, and disposing of wastewater at the rate of 10,000 gallons per day or greater and which is owned, operated or maintained by any person or entity other than Butts County, Georgia, the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority, or any municipality within Butts County, Georgia. Developer means any person, corporation, partnership, joint venture, public body or legal entity that is selling, offering for sale, dividing, subdividing or developing property for residential, commercial or industrial use. Development Activity means any construction or expansion of a building, structure, use, or any change in use of a building or structure, or any change in the use of land which results in a change in anticipated utility demands. Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others including such meaning as given under all applicable federal and state rules, regulations and statutes. Economic Development means any development activity determined by the authority as extraordinary economic development. Encumber means to legally obligate by contract or otherwise commit to use by appropriation or other official act of the authority. Feepayor means that person who pays a Capital Recovery Fee, or his or her successor in interest, with the right or entitlement to any refund of a previously paid Capital Recovery Fee which is required by this ordinance and which has been expressly transferred or assigned to the successor in interest. In the absence of an express transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to any refund of previously paid Capital Recovery Fees, the right or entitlement shall be deemed "not to run with the land". Flammable means any material which is easily ignited and burns with unusual rapidity. Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection and/or treatment system. Garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the domestic and commercial handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. Health Officer means the director of the County Board of Health or other person designated by the Board of Commissioners and their duly appointed assistants. Individual Fee Determination means a Capital Recovery Fee determined by the Administrator based on an Individual Fee Calculation Study. Individual Fee Calculation Study means the documentation prepared by a feepayor to allow determination of a Capital Recovery Fee other than by use of the fee schedule described in Sec. 90-78.b of this ordinance as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-4(g). Industrial wastes means the wastewater or liquid waste, of whatever nature, arising out of any manufacturing, industrial processing, fabricating, treating, renovating, or other commercial trade or business operation, as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. Infiltration/Inflow means groundwater and surface water which leaks in sewers through cracked pipes, joints, manholes, or other openings. Interceptor line, trunk line or outfall line means the sewer line leading from owner/developer's property to the authority's existing sewer line, treatment plant or treatment plant site. Such lines normally collect sewage or could collect sewage from more than one property owner and transport the sewage to the sewage treatment plant. May is permissive. Methodology Report means the technical report entitled "Sewer Capital Recovery Fee and Rate Differential Study", dated August, 1999, prepared for the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority by Black and Veatch Management Consulting. Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. Nitrification means the conversion of nitrogenous matter into nitrates. Normal wastewater means wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewers in which the average concentration of total suspended solids is not more than 350 milligrams per liter (mg/l) BOD5 is not more than 300 mg/l, total phosphorous is not more than 15 mg/l, total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than 20 mg/l, and the total flow is not more than 25,000 gallons per day. Objectionable means unacceptable, unsatisfactory, or displeasing to the physical senses. Outfall line. See Interceptor line. Owner means any individual, firm, company, partnership, corporation, institution, trust, organization, executor, or administrator owning property in the county. pH means the reciprocal of the logarithm of the hydrogen in concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of 7.0 and a hydrogen ion concentration of 10.7. Phosphorous means the chemical element phosphorous and its several compounds. Phosphorous removal shall mean the removal of phosphorous and phosphorous compounds by biological or chemical treatment or a combination of both. Pollution means dredged soil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical waste, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, industrial waste, municipal waste and agricultural waste discharged into the waters of the state. Present Value means the value, in present day dollars, of past, present or future payments, or contributions or dedications of goods, services, materials, construction, or money. Private Development Agreement means a mutual agreement between the authority and a developer regarding development activity whereby the project's proportionate share of system improvements is funded through a source other than Capital Recovery Fees. Private Sewer System means any sewer system capable of collecting, pumping, treating, transporting, and disposing of wastewater at the rate of 10,000 gallons per day or greater and which is owned, operated or maintained by any person or entity other than Butts County, Georgia, the Butts County, et al. Water and Sewer Authority, or any municipality within Butts County, Georgia. Project Improvements means site improvements and facilities that are planned and designed to provide service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience of the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements. The character of the improvement shall control a determination of whether an improvement is a project improvement or system improvement, and the physical location of the improvement on-site, or off-site, shall not be considered determinative of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement. If an improvement or facility provides, or will provide, more than incidental service or facilities capacity to persons other than users or occupants of a particular project, the improvement or facility is a System Improvement and shall not be considered a Project Improvement. Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of foods that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (27 centimeters) in any dimension. Proportionate Share means that portion of the cost of System Improvements which is reasonably related to the demands and needs of a Project. Public sewer means a sanitary sewer owned and/or maintained by the authority, and does not include building sewers or sewer connections or municipal sewers not under the authority's jurisdiction. Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. Service Area means a geographically defined area in which a defined set of public facilities provide, or are proposed to provide, service to existing, or future development. Sewage collector means all sewer lines, pumping stations and appurtenances thereto that are located on or required to be constructed in order to service the owner/developer's property with sewer service. Sewer system means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, transporting, and disposing of sewage, and all appurtenances thereto. Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. Shall is mandatory. Suspended solids means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in the most recent edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater and referred to as nonfilterable residue. System Improvements means capital improvements which are designed to provide service to the community at large, in contrast to Project Improvements. System Improvement Costs means costs incurred to provide public facilities capacity to serve new growth and development, including the costs of planning, design, engineering, construction, land acquisition, and land improvement for the construction or reconstruction of facility improvements or expansions. System improvement costs include the construction contract price, surveying and engineering fees, related land and easement acquisition costs (including land purchases, court awards and costs, attorneys' fees, and expert witness fees), and expenses incurred for qualified staff or any qualified engineer, planner, architect, landscape architect, or financial consultant for preparing or updating the capital improvements element and administrative costs of up to three (3) percent of the total of all other costs. Total Kjeldahl nitrogen means the total of organic and ammonia nitrogen as defined in Standard Methods. Trunk line. See Interceptor line. Unpolluted water means water of a quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. Unsanitary means unclean, unhealthy, or harmful to public health. Wastewater means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. (See also Sewage.) Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat residential, commercial and industrial wastes and dispose of effluent. Wastewater treatment works means an arrangement of devices and structures for the treatment of wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge and such term shall also mean the sewage disposal system and sewage transportation system where applicable in construing the rules and regulations of the county or authority and their legal documents and contracts; sometimes used as synonymous with the terms "waste treatment plant," "wastewater treatment plant" or "water pollution control plant." Watercourse means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water, whether continuously or intermittently. DIVISION 2. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS[5]
